questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and can occur idiopathically or secondary to HIV infection, sickle cell disease, heroin use, severe obesity, and interferon therapy. The most common renal complications of primary SS are tubulointerstitial nephritis and type 1 renal tubular acidosis. Glomerular involvement in primary SS is rare and, when it does occur, typically manifests as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis or membranous nephropathy, not FSGS.

B) INCORRECT:

Lofgren syndrome occurs in 5–10% of patients with sarcoidosis, which occurs more commonly in women and can manifest with features of pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough), keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia, and parotid enlargement. However, in patients with sarcoidosis, chest imaging would typically show hilar lymphadenopathy, which is the earliest manifestation of pulmonary involvement. Primary SS, which is more likely in this patient, is not associated with Lofgren syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with Sjogren syndrome (SS) have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the exocrine glands, particularly the parotid gland. The most important risk factor for lymphoma development in SS is persistent salivary gland enlargement. Although the pathophysiology of lymphoma development in SS is not entirely known, B-cell activation and chronic inflammation are thought to play a role. MALT lymphoma is the most common lymphoma in patients with SS, followed by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Other common complications in patients with SS are related to xerostomia and include gastroesophageal reflux disease, atrophic oral candidiasis, and increased risk of dental caries. Patients with SS can develop a dry cough as a result of xerotrachea and xerobronchitis (the most likely cause in this patient with a normal chest CT) or interstitial lung disease. Patients with primary SS are often positive for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, both of which are specific types of ANA.

Parotid enlargement is more common in primary than in secondary SS.

D) INCORRECT:

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is associated with IgG4-related disease, which can manifest with xerostomia, xerophthalmia, and parotid gland enlargement. A dry cough may also be seen in IgG4-related disease as a result of interstitial lung disease. However, positive antinuclear antibody titers are not seen in IgG4-related disease. Instead, serum IgG4 antibody titers are often well above the normal range (≥ 2 times the upper limit). RPF is not typically associated with primary SS, the diagnosis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE) is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically occurs in women and can cause a dry cough (due to pleuritis or interstitial lung disease), fatigue, positive ANA titers, and, occasionally, features of secondary SS (keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia). However, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers indicate a different cause for increased ANA titers. Moreover, patients with SLE usually have a malar or discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers (rather than tongue fissures), arthralgia, and/or hematological abnormalities, none of which this patient has. Primary SS has been reported to cause autoimmune myocarditis but is not associated with LSE.
questions.hint: Features of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry mouth and tongue fissures due to xerostomia; blurred vision, injected conjunctiva, and decreased tear film break-up time due to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in a patient without a history of another autoimmune disorder are consistent with primary Sjogren syndrome (SS).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of itchiness in both eyes. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing solid food. She is sexually active with her husband and has recently noticed increased pain with sexual intercourse. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Her sister has vitiligo. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oropharyngeal examination shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. Ophthalmologic examination shows normal visual acuity and scleral injection in both eyes. A filter paper placed on the patient's lower eyelid wicks 3 mm of moisture after 5 minutes. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Labial (rather than parotid) salivary gland biopsy is an accurate test for SS and would show sialadenitis with dense focal lymphocytic infiltrations. However, a salivary gland biopsy is only necessary to confirm the diagnosis in patients without evidence of systemic autoimmunity. Therefore, a less invasive test should be performed first.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy can be performed in patients with dysphagia, which this patient has. Dysphagia is often seen in patients with SS due to xerostomia. However, upper endoscopy would only exclude other causes of dysphagia (e.g., malignancy), which is not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of SS. Other gastrointestinal manifestations of SS include dyspepsia and reflux esophagitis.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with SS, urinalysis can show signs of glomerulonephritis or interstitial nephritis (e.g., proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts), which are possible extraglandular vasculitic manifestations of SS. However, vasculitic manifestations only occur in approx. 10% of patients with SS. Therefore, urinalysis is not the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Sialometry is a noninvasive test to measure saliva flow and can quantify salivary hypofunction in patients with xerostomia due to Sjogren syndrome (SS). While sialometry can support the diagnosis of SS, it is mainly performed in research settings and not generally used to diagnose SS.

E) CORRECT:

Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies and anti-La/SSB antibodies are present in about 70% of patients with SS and confirm the diagnosis if seen in combination with typical clinical features of this condition (e.g., sicca syndrome). Other autoantibodies seen in patients with SS include antinuclear antibodies, which are positive in up to 97% of cases, and rheumatoid factor, which is positive in > 90% of cases of secondary SS (i.e., secondary to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus). In patients without serological evidence of autoimmunity or concomitant autoimmune disease, labial salivary gland biopsy is essential to confirm or exclude the diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's itchy eyes and abnormal Schirmer test due to xerophthalmia in combination with dysphagia due to xerostomia indicate sicca syndrome, which is typical of Sjogren syndrome (SS). Patients with SS can also present with dyspareunia caused by vaginal dryness.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressively worsening dryness of her eyes and mouth, along with intermittent bilateral parotid gland swelling, to the clinic. She reports morning stiffness in her wrists and knees. Examination reveals mildly swollen parotid glands, conjunctival injection, and a dry buccal mucosa. A Schirmer test shows reduced tear production (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Sodium
140 mmol/L
134 - 146 mmol/L


Potassium
3.0 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L


Bicarbonate
16 mmol/L
21 - 28 mmol/L


Chloride
109 mmol/L
97 - 108 mmol/L


Urine




 pH
Consistently above 5.5
4.3 - 8



Which of the following best explains the underlying cause of this patient’s metabolic abnormality?

choices.text: Increased ammonia generation causing hyperchloremic acidosis
Excessive bicarbonate loss in the proximal tubule
Inadequate aldosterone production in the adrenal cortex
Defective hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased ammonia generation is a compensatory response to acidosis, not a cause of it. The patient's non-anion gap metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia and high urine pH suggests a defect in distal acid secretion, not altered ammonia production.

B) INCORRECT:

Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RTA type 2) involves bicarbonate loss in the proximal tubule, leading to metabolic acidosis. Initially, urine pH may be high, but as serum bicarbonate levels fall, the distal nephron compensates, resulting in a urine pH less than 5.5. The consistently elevated urine pH in this patient is inconsistent with proximal RTA.

C) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone deficiency, seen in type IV RTA, typically causes hyperkalemia due to reduced potassium excretion. This patient's hypokalemia and high urine pH are inconsistent with aldosterone deficiency, which usually results in normal or decreased urine pH.

D) CORRECT:

Distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA type 1) is characterized by defective hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron, leading to an inability to acidify urine despite systemic metabolic acidosis. This results in a persistently elevated urine pH (above 5.5) and hypokalemia, as seen in the laboratory data. The condition is often associated with autoimmune disorders like Sjögren's syndrome, which manifests with symptoms such as dry eyes and mouth, and can affect the distal renal tubules, contributing to the development of distal RTA.

Key learning point: Sjogren's syndrome can be associated with Type 1 renal tubular acidosis, which is characterized by hypokalemia and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis due to a defect in distal hydrogen ion secretion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of itchiness in both eyes. She also reports difficulty swallowing solid food and has recently experienced increased pain with sexual intercourse. She is sexually active with her husband. Her medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. Oropharyngeal examination reveals dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. Ophthalmologic examination shows normal visual acuity and scleral injection in both eyes. A filter paper placed on her lower eyelid wicks 3 mm of moisture after 5 minutes. Which one of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy can be performed in patients with dysphagia, which this patient has. Dysphagia is often seen in patients with SS due to xerostomia. However, upper endoscopy would only exclude other causes of dysphagia (e.g., malignancy), which is not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of SS. Other gastrointestinal manifestations of SS include dyspepsia and reflux esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sialometry is a noninvasive test to measure saliva flow and can quantify salivary hypofunction in patients with xerostomia due to Sjogren syndrome (SS). While sialometry can support the diagnosis of SS, it is mainly performed in research settings and not generally used to diagnose SS.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with SS, urinalysis can show signs of glomerulonephritis or interstitial nephritis (e.g., proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts), which are possible extraglandular vasculitic manifestations of SS. However, vasculitic manifestations only occur in approx. 10% of patients with SS. Therefore, urinalysis is not the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies and anti-La/SSB antibodies are present in about 70% of patients with SS and confirm the diagnosis if seen in combination with typical clinical features of this condition (e.g., sicca syndrome). Other autoantibodies seen in patients with SS include antinuclear antibodies, which are positive in up to 97% of cases, and rheumatoid factor, which is positive in > 90% of cases of secondary SS (i.e., secondary to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus). In patients without serological evidence of autoimmunity or concomitant autoimmune disease, labial salivary gland biopsy is essential to confirm or exclude the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome is confirmed by detecting anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies in patients with characteristic sicca symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Labial (rather than parotid) salivary gland biopsy is an accurate test for SS and would show sialadenitis with dense focal lymphocytic infiltrations. However, a salivary gland biopsy is only necessary to confirm the diagnosis in patients without evidence of systemic autoimmunity. Therefore, a less invasive test should be performed first.
questions.hint: This patient's itchy eyes and abnormal Schirmer test due to xerophthalmia in combination with dysphagia due to xerostomia indicate sicca syndrome, which is typical of Sjogren syndrome (SS). Patients with SS can also present with dyspareunia caused by vaginal dryness.
